text: I think this edit is nice - and although long it is covering a lot of information. By including headings for the sections and numbering the actionable items to join the group I think it will still be easy to read!

text:
Draft Slack orientation message (it had hyperlinked text on my notes app, but it looks like I’ll need to paste URLs for slack messages):


Welcome to the Open Science Student Support Group’s Slack Workspace—we’re excited to have you here!

To help you make the most of this workspace, we’d like to briefly go over how Slack works, and how we’ve organized our workspace.

Getting Started

We encourage you to download the Slack app for desktop or mobile (or both) so that you will receive notifications from Slack. If you only use Slack in your browser you are likely to miss out on important communications from the group.

What is Slack?

Slack is a channel-based messaging platform. With Slack, people can work together more effectively, connect all their software tools and services, and find the information they need to do their best work.

A Slack workspace is made up of channels, where team members can communicate and work together:

- A channel is a single place for a team to share messages, tools, and files.
- Team members can join and leave channels as needed.
- When messages and files are shared in public channels, you can search your team's conversation history in Slack to find them.
- Discussions in channels are organized through threads. To start or reply to a thread click/tap on the message you’d like to reply to and tap the Start in Thread icon, or Add a Reply button.

Team members can also Direct Message (DM) each other. DMs can be useful in a number of ways:

- A substitute for an in-person, 1-1 conversation.
- An easy way to catch up with a teammate.
- A quick and simple way to ask questions.

You can learn more about working with Slack here <https://slack.com/intl/en-ca/help/categories/360000049043|https://slack.com/intl/en-ca/help/categories/360000049043>

How is our Slack workspace organized?

We have created several public channels in our workspace, each tailored to a specific purpose:

1. #general is...
2. #resources is...
3. #social is...

Community Guidelines

In the interest of creating an inclusive and supportive group, you are expected to follow the University of Calgary’s Student Conduct policies.

attachments.title: Where work happens
attachments.text: Slack is where work flows. It's where the people you need, the information you share, and the tools you use come together to get things done.
attachments.fallback: Slack Help Center: Where work happens

text: Okay so just to update everyone: I double-checked the times I put in the doodle poll, and it turns out that I had overlooked two conflicts: with 615 on Thursday, and with 625 on Tuesday, leaving only 3 time points in our doodle poll (and feel free to triple-check me ^^). I removed these times from the doodle poll, no need to fill it in again :wink:

text: I think the blurb is great! And the addition of the headings does make it easy to read too.

elements.text: I think the blurb is great! And the addition of the headings does make it easy to read too.

text: <@U01AGDAUB1S> on adding something on research dissemination: How about adding it as one of the example topics we mention? So e.g. “reproducible workflows, preregistration and research dissemination”. For me the accessibility of science also addresses this topic, but if you’d like to add something somewhere else more explicitly, I’m open to that too!

text: <@U01AA7U2ECA> I think that example sentence is better than the current one. Research dissemination is likely more captivating and relevant to people than transparent writing.
